nodes.bodyText: Might as well make this string a constant instead of repeating it.
I don't see this string being used in more than one place
I see. It looks like the repeated string is the one for close.
"; abandoning it."

So we're marking this constructor as deprecated so users can use the MultiplexingClient instead. But isn't this true only for customers who want to use multiplexed connections? Wouldn't this still be useful to customers who don't want to use multiplexed connections?

nodes.bodyText: I'm doing this to impress upon users that we won't be supporting that transport client anymore, and that users who want better multiplexing support should use the multiplexing client. I'm also doing it to cut down on confusion from customers as to which multiplexing client they should use if they are starting from scratch

There really wasn't a good reason to have a list of configs or the protocol at this level. I've delegated that responsibility down to the transport connection since that layer actually needs the protocol value and configs

It never made sense that we defined the possibility of multiplexing in this interface considering only AMQP supports it, so I've removed it
Not a customer-breaking change?

For the uninitiated, we use Fortify to scan for security vulnerabilities and other code smells. This file contains the false positives that Fortify complains about, but have manually been verified to be fine.

nodes.bodyText: We should confirm with Avneet that 1000 devices is sufficient for the customers' requirements.
We (Avneet and I) have already shared this with the customer and they seemed fine with it
I'd also like us to confirm this restriction with Avneet.
A single TCP connection cannot connect to two hosts, so I doubt this will be an issue
This doesn't look threadsafe. Shouldn't it be?
It should be. I'll add a lock to synchronize the register/unregister calls onto
I think 186 - 200 should be in a synchronized block
This is an interesting case. Why do we have this restriction, and what options might we have for fixing that?

The problem here is that we cannot remove the last device session from a multiplexed connection without the whole multiplexed connection getting shut down. One option here is to just allow the connection to close if it is the last device session to be unregistered, but that feels unintuitive to me

It is interesting. I think this needs to be more clear, maybe we should first look for the device in the devicelist and throw if we can't find it.
then if it's there and it's the last one, while maintaining thread safety, close the deviceIO and allow the multiplex client to not have any devices.
just as you would when you first initialize it. just a thought ... curious what else we can do here.
I like the idea of returning to the initialized state, however I recall seeing that when initializing you had to have at least 1 device then too.
Resolving this thread since the multplexing client now lets you have a multiplexed connection open with no devices registered
As long as we're fixing this, I don't see why it would be capitalized. It isn't a proper noun, right?

Strings outside of javadocs don't support the {@ link } notation, if that is what you are getting at.
ah, there is no equivalent of nameof in java. Fair enough
this check seems useful, why remove it?

nodes.bodyText: does DISCONNECTED status means all the tasks schedulers are shut down?
Yes
double negative method name. We can just call it verifyRegisteredIfMultiplexing
can this.deviceIO be null? then shouldn't this method throw?
I see that it can be null if it's using multiplexing ... ignore my previous commnet.
if we had a boolean flag that we would set if multiplexing was registered, we could just check that  ... just a thought

We sort of have that flag already at the DeviceClient level in the Enum ioTHubConnectionType
Unfortunately, the internal client level also encompasses the ModuleClient, which has no concept of multiplexing. I'm a bit on the fence about adding a boolean about multiplexing at this level because of that
fair enough. just wanted to bring it up if it might add value to not rely on contextual knowledge about how the multiplexing is designed to read the code.

How about a method isClientMultiplexing() and have the body of that return this.deviceIO != null. It reads better, and if you later device to change the condition, you won't have to update it in several places.

I've added a isMultiplexed flag within the InternalClient now to make this stuff more obvious, and so that it can be referenced when we want to block certain things like setting the proxySettings of a multiplexed device
nit: break this line into multiple lines for readability
good catch, we can probably check to see if it's null at the beginning and throw there. before we check for anything else.
is this the only indication of the client using multiplexing? no boolean indicator anywhere? it would probably be useful to have.

We have an enum ioTHubConnectionType at the DeviceClient level, but not at the internal client level. I'm on the fence about adding one since ModuleClient also uses this class and has no concept of multiplexing

can you elaborate why we don't have to close every device client as well?
like this:
deviceClient.close()
I can add a comment about this, but deviceClient.Close() only closes the deviceIO layer, and that layer is closed by this class instead
is this limitation documented somewhere that we can link this paragraph to?
Sadly no. I had to ask for this information from a service team member directly
do we check to see if we are overwriting any proxy setting on individual devices? just as warning maybe? it's an unlikely event but might be useful to warn the user about
should we throw in this case? can't we just be resilient to this?

We'd need to at least log a warning about attempting to re-register an already registered client. I'm of the mindset that anyone who does that is probably doing it accidentally, and should be notified more strongly with this exception

I don't disagree, but throwing is not just a warning. I don't feel too strongly about this, but I think if we can move on with the operation with no setbacks or issues, we should try doing that. this seems a fairly innocent operation to add an already existing device to multiplexing client.
Fair enough. I'll make this just log what happens instead. I guess it is analogous to trying to open an already open device client, and we do allow that without throwing
is this check case insensitive?
It is, but it should be insensitive. I'll fix it

This can have multiplex in the name of the call back to avoid confusion ... maybe onDeviceMultiplexSessionEstablished
same for the method below.

same on line 39
Seems this might take a long time. No way to parallelize?
Not without spawning other threads, which is a bit much since we should aim to support constrained devices
I guess we could make it an option (even later), of how many threads to handle parallelization across the clients. Default would be 1, which would maintain current behavior.

Reads a bit funny. I feel not having a subject on the sentence makes it sound weird too. Thoughts?
A device client cannot be registered to a multiplexing client that specifies a different transport protocol.
Other errors could use similar clean up
same for these guys, if this is only applicable to multiplexed sessions, it would be nice to have that in the name.

nodes.bodyText: How about we make this 1000 a constant, and refer to it in the error message too?
Could be a public constant too, to let users know the max number of multiplexed devices

I'm a bit hesitant to make it a public variable because the service may change these limits arbitrarily later. We don't want customers using this value directly if we update it from 1,000 to 100,000 to match the service limits. I'd rather just document it in the headers clearly.

If the service updates it, and we've been checking it in our code, they'll be broken anyway. We'd just be making the limits we're adhering to public.
I'd say either the client SDK doesn't check these limits, and just lets the service return an error, or we share the limits we're abiding by.
Okay, I can make these public then
:D why did we have a queue if it wasn't allowed to be larger than 1 !!! strange ...

nodes.bodyText: plural

Poor grammar. Maybe this?
"Attempting device session reconnect: attempt {}"
How about "Attempting to reconnect device session: attempt {}"?
sure
I mentioned it elsewhere, but don't see the comment anymore. Bracing here seems to follow .NET style guidelines, not Java.
We have wildly different bracing style in track 1 repos than what we have in track 2. This is standard in our track 1 repo so far, albeit we could certainly change
Hey, I'm not going to complain. Let's embrace .NET style everywhere. :)
This might also be slow for 1000 devices. Thoughts on parallelizing?
There isn't a way to speed this up without introducing more threading. This is just putting a key value pair in a hashmap, which shouldn't be much of a bottleneck anyways
Do we not want to log each device's connection status?
We do log them above
Connection reconnection? Seems a bit redundant.
plural should be "Latches"

What is CBS besides a TV network?
In .NET we'd case this as Cbs. All caps for Java?
"CBS" is an acronym for "Claims Based Security"
We don't typically lowercase the tail end of an acronym in Java, no
Can we add some code comments for things like this? Spell out CBS and maybe provide a link to what it is somewhere.
There is no formal documentation on this CBS link that I could link to, but I can add some comments to clarify what CBS is
Grammar, semi-colon instead of comma.
Any comment here to indicate the transport client is being deprecated?

nodes.bodyText: We don't have a way to distinguish exceptions except by the message?

This is for the service client (AMQP) in particular, and we don't have any sort of proper exception hierarchy there, no. This is a pretty special case, I'll admit. I don't have a better way to accomplish this though
Is this not already covered by the previous import?
You'd think so, but no. The star does not recurse
So anyone can change this, not just this class?
I can make these fields private and make getters so they are readonly, sure
Can we give this a more specific name? TelemetryAckCallback?

As discussed, I think this would work better as a HashMap of <string deviceId, DeviceClient deviceClient> and illustrate sending telemetry as devices (and other operations) by looking up a device client by the device Id.
To iterate, you'd have a list of your registered devices, use that to look up your HashMap, and perform the action on the DeviceClient.
Probably should print the number of messages acked, and how many more you are waiting for.
Consider adding big comment blocks to announce what the next code block demonstrates.

what if the deviceIO already exists on this device? (it has already been opened independently from the multiplex connection)
what I mean is that the pre-existing device IO needs to be disposed. we also need tests for that :D
I think I'll throw in that scenario. To me, the scenario where a user tries to register a device client instance that is already open sounds more accidental than deliberate
how do we prevent users from setting a different proxy setting after they are registered to the multiplexing client? there is a public API on the internal client that allows setting a proxySetting
I've added a flag in the internal client for if the client is multiplexing or not. When the flag is set, calls to setProxy will fail
nit: this message could be in a const string, similar to MULTIPLEXING_CLOSE_ERROR_MESSAGE.
I am not really clear what this means; is this set only by a multiplexing client, to indicate to this device client's DeviceIO layer (or someone else) that it is a multiplexed client?

It is called only by the multiplexing client that "owns" this client, yes. The value set here is used in some if cases when a user tries to set options that are only available to non-multiplexed devices for example
It is also used to differentiate between what the old TransportClient allows vs what the new MultiplexingClient allows, hence why this enum has separate values for those two cases.
q - for a non-multiplexed device, what is the difference between an auth session timeout and a device session timeout?

The former is how long the SDK should wait for the CBS session and its links to open, and the latter is how long the SDK should wait for the worker links (twin/telemetry/methods) to open. In the multiplexing case, the authentication session timeout is considered a "Multiplexing level" option, whereas the device session timeout can be set per registered device client.

question on a slightly unrelated-to-multiplexing note - I recently found that if the .NET sdk is initially disconnected right after initialization, it reports a "Disconnected" state, even though it is actively retrying at this point. Does java behave as expected?
The Java SDK only reports when the connection status changes, so it should work as expected in that case, yes
this line and the two below it are repeated in this block - rebase issue?
Good catch, it does appear to be a rebase issue
Q - is this called only for multiplexed devices?

nodes.bodyText: Yes, but both the old TransportClient and the new MultiplexingClient call into this. In both cases, they set the deviceIO of each device client to be the same deviceIO instance. That way they all share the same connection, worker threads, etc.

nodes.bodyText: In which scenario would a user set one with a deviceId and without, or do both of them behave the same way? I see that this is publicly exposed under DeviceIO, but I don't think users access this directly, correct?
This actually doesn't need to be public, so I'll make this package private

The deviceId is specified to indicate that it will be called when connection status events occur to that specific device. For instance if the SAS token expires for just that device, then the user's device level callback would be fired
registerMultiplexingConnectionStateCallback on the other hand is strictly for multiplexed connection level events, like TCP connection drops
q - would deviceIO ever be null? Would it be null if I were to call multiplexedClient.close() twice, in succession?

It will never be null. This check was a remnant of back when the deviceIO was only created after registering the first device client. Now that the constructor builds this, and it is declared final, I can remove this null check
Closing/opening the client has no affect on what deviceIO object is set here. Only the constructor sets it. No one else sets it to null
q - does deviceIO.close() close the transport layer? (the amqp connection)
Yes, and it also stops the worker threads from spawning to handle IO events
I remember reading above that each device client can have its own retry policy. Would the device client level retry policy (if provided) override the multiplexing client level retry policy?

No. Each device client's retry policy is only consulted when a message send on that particular device fails, or if that particular device has its session lost. For connection level events like TCP connection drop, only the multiplexing level retry policy is consulted
We call it out as such in our javadoc comments, right?

if we perform the registration operation again for a device that is already registered, will there be an issue? I am thinking abut how heavy this for loop will be, for ~1000 devices, and if making registration idempotent is an option.
Good point. I can make this list a set instead to make this more idempotent
HashSet's in Java are basically O(1) to add, so that will be a nice performance boost

I am a bit confused about how deviceIO works. This is what I thought, but now I think I might be misunderstanding it:

deviceIO is the "interface" for transforming device client operations to the transport layer
this.deviceIO is the deviceIO associated with the multiplexing client, which is then getting assigned to the device client instance.
In that case, how do we differentiate between the deviceIO for device1 vs device2?

DeviceIO is a layer whose primary responsibility is managing the worker threads of the SDK. When multiplexing, all devices share the same deviceIO instance and the same worker threads. Within the deviceIO layer is a reference to the transport layer. The deviceIO layer more or less just forwards all telemetry/twin/method messages down to the transport layer. I hope that clears it up a bit

In that case, how do we differentiate between the deviceIO for device1 vs device2?

When multiplexing, they have the same deviceIO instance
it is safe to assume that network or service related disconnection would always be accompanied by by a throwable, correct?
Sort of. Sometimes the connection is lost without any meaningful context other than the event itself, but we do build a default throwable in cases like that
For the graceful close case, there will be no throwable though
Is the call to Open() thread safe?
Not at this level, but it is at the MultiplexingClient level
q - is sas token renewal handled in some other layer?
To be honest, I don't know why this is here. It isn't very helpful, but I'll leave it alone just in case customers are catching this particular exception because we don't throw it anywhere else
q - would the user ever create an instance of IotHubTransport directly? The reason I ask is, we already have these checks in the higher layers, so I was wondering if this check was even required.

Customer's wouldn't create this IotHubTransport object directly, no. These checks aren't something that a customer would hit, but it may be hit by a developer who does something wrong (like tries to multiplex over MQTT or something.)
I can remove it if you'd prefer, but this error message is more helpful to a developer on our team than a class cast failure exception that they'd get when they try to open later.
No, you are right, it'll help against accidental misuse within the library.
For my understanding - What is the difference between status callback and mux status callback?

Mux callback is fired for connection level events (like TCP connection drop) whereas device specific callbacks are fired for device specific events (like authentication failed to due the key in use being cycled, or if the device isn't registered)
